19. 
entirely on the relation between local evaporation and 
precipitation. At least two important considerations 
are ignored in this assertion, namely the possibility 
of denudation from the under surface and the effect of 
climatic changes in the remote high level regions from 
which the ice springs. It is impossible to believe 
that in making so bold a statement Mr Dines has duly 
considered all the facts which were at his disposal. 
On pages 483 and 484 Mr R.H.Curtis comments 
on the exposure of anemometers in a manner which shows 
that he has been at no pains to inform himself of the 
difficulties experienced. 
This is especially evident in his remarks 
on the 'self recording' anemometer and the 'sight 
indicating' anemometer. The difficulties we experienced 
with the first instrument have already been pointed out 
and the substantial inaccuracy of Mr Curtis' comments 
must be apparent. 
As regards his remarks on the 'sight indicating' 
anemometer one has to ask how an observer cumbered with 
mits, a lantern and a recording board, walking through 
snow and often compelled to cling to a guide rope, could 
have also carried a portable anemometer to and from the 
observing station. And again whether Mr Curtis has 
ever attempted to get a 'mean' reading of the instrument 
when the fluid was oscillating rapidly between such limits 
as 16 and 26.
